ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PUBLIC TRANSPORT SYSTEM

(Security)

1.  Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong  asked the Minister for Transport (a) what are the measures taken to improve the security of Singapore's public transport system, especially the rail system, given the terrorist bombings in Madrid;  (b) how effective will these measures  be in thwarting  terrorist  attacks;  (c) how much will the measures cost; and (d) how will the cost be paid for.

2.  Mdm Cynthia Phua asked the Minister for Transport whether (a) there is any security system that can check to prevent harmful materials like explosive chemicals and bombs being brought into MRT stations; and (b) the security review on the MRT can be expanded to include big bus interchanges as well, as both transport systems have heavy human traffic.

Column: 2695

     The Minister for Transport (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong):  Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos 1 and 2 together as they both address the same topic?

     Mr Speaker:  Yes, carry on.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir,  Mdm Cynthia Phua asked if there is any security system that can prevent harmful materials from being brought into MRT stations. Today, various types of detection equipment are available for screening passengers and their baggage.  However, with over 4 million passenger trips made on our bus and MRT systems each day, it would not be possible to impose 100% security check without severely degrading the efficiency and operation of our public transport system.  

 

     Let me assure Members that the Government, together with the train operators, has always taken a pro-active approach to making sure that our train network is safe and secure.  Even before the Madrid train bombings, we had conducted security planning and surveys for our MRT system, and implemented many security measures. For example, the operators have tightened security of the access to vital installations, and have installed CCTVs to monitor the MRT network. LTA is also incorporating similar security features into the design of the Circle Line.   In addition, the Police carry out routine patrols of the MRT stations. The transport operators, LTA and the security agencies have also conducted several exercises to ensure that we are able to respond effectively to security threats to our public transport system.

 

     In light of the Madrid incident, the Government and our public transport operators have stepped up measures to increase the level of staff vigilance.   As I announced last week,  the Government has set up a high level Committee to continually review the security of our

Column: 2696

public transport system. The Committee will undertake a comprehensive review of the public transport security arrangements, and will make its recommendations taking into account international "best practices".  This review will cover both our rail and bus systems, including bus interchanges.

 

    Ms Ng asked how effective these security measures will be.  Experience elsewhere has shown that it is very difficult to fully protect any public transport system without drastically reducing its function and efficiency.  However, the security measures that we have introduced, together with future enhancements, will help to deter and prevent a large scale attack that will seriously cripple the public transport system. 

 

   While the Government will continue to work closely with the operators to keep our public transport system secure, commuters also have an important role to play. We have thus embarked on a public education programme to increase public awareness and vigilance. The operators have put up security posters at MRT stations, and are regularly broadcasting security messages reminding commuters to report any unattended or suspicious packages.   Similar measures will be extended to the bus interchanges. All commuters can help to ensure the security of our public transport system by being vigilant. This will ultimately safeguard their own safety.

 

    The Member asked how much the additional security features will cost.   This will largely depend on the recommendations of the Committee as it undertakes the review.  However, since the public transport system is for the general public, the security of the system should be the collective responsibility of the Government, the public transport operators and the commuters.   It is therefore reasonable

Column: 2697

that the costs of security measures be shared.   The Committee will ensure that only security measures that are necessary will be added so that the cost borne by the commuters will be minimised and kept reasonable.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines):  Sir, may I ask the Minister when the recommendations will be out?  May I also ask the Minister how minimal will be the price increase for commuters?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir, in fact, the Committee has been working for the last month or so and as soon as it finalises any recommendation it will proceed to implement it.  Let me give an example - the decision to remove litter bins from the MRT stations.  The moment that was decided upon, the operators were told to remove them.  The decision to increase public awareness resulted in the posters being made and broadcast announcements being finalised and those were implemented straightaway.  The Committee will not wait until all the decisions have been made before proceeding to implement them.  They will decide and proceed to implement as and when they are made.

 

     In terms of the quantum of increase, we do not really know, but I can assure Members that the Committee will ensure that whatever is implemented will be practical, cost effective and the cost increase will be kept to a minimal.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast):  Can I ask the Minister how will the deployment of train marshals be carried out such that it will not cause undue alarm among commuters?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  The decision to deploy train marshals has not been made yet.  It is an issue that is being studied by the Committee.

Column: 2698

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member):  Sir, since the Police has actually cut down the presence and operating hours of the Neighbourhood Police Posts due to lack of demand, would the Transport Minister consider working with the Police to site some of the NPPs at the MRT stations for better policing, control, checks and police presence?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir, I think the Member should direct the question to the Minister for Home Affairs.

Column: 2698

SINGAPORE CARRIERS' RIGHT TO FLY BEYOND AUSTRALIA

3.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Transport whether the Australian authorities have agreed to allow Singapore Airlines or any Singapore-owned airline the right to fly beyond Australia to the United States, as Qantas is now allowed to fly beyond Singapore to Europe and to compete for the regional market from a base in Singapore.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Australian government has not granted Singapore carriers the right to fly beyond Australia to the United States on the trans-pacific route.

    Under the current Singapore-Australia air services agreement (ASA), which was last expanded in September last year, both Singapore and Australia designated airlines are restricted in their 5th freedom rights to fly beyond each other's country.

    Given our close bilateral relationship, including the recently concluded Singapore-Australia FTA, and the many business and social linkages between our people, Singapore has always been ready to conclude a full Open Skies Agreement (OSA) with Australia.  A full OSA will enable Australian carriers to freely fly to and beyond Singapore, without any restrictions, to all points, including major European and Asian destinations.  Likewise, Singapore carriers will be able to fly

Column: 2699

to and beyond Australia.  Specifically, the Australian public will also have more choices of airlines to choose from on the trans-pacific route to the United States.  An OSA will be a win-win outcome for both Singapore and Australian carriers.   More importantly, it will bring significant benefits to both economies given the sizeable multiplier effects of increased air links between and beyond both countries.

     However, Australia was not ready to conclude an OSA in September last year as the global industry had just begun recovering then.  Nevertheless, Singapore and Australia had agreed "to continue to work towards the conclusion of an open-skies agreement and to consider further liberalisation, including trans-pacific rights, when there is greater stability in the global aviation environment".

     Since then, the outlook for global aviation environment has been very positive.   The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has in fact projected a growth of 7% in global passenger traffic this year.   For routes within Asia Pacific, a growth of 14% can be expected because we are comparing against a very low base last year because of SARS.

     Qantas Airways has also reported positive financial results.   It had announced that the company's businesses have returned to profitability and that it is in good position to take advantage "of what appears to be a return to more stable market conditions".   As there are enough indicators that the global and regional aviation environment has stabilised, we are engaging our Australian counterparts on realising the full open skies agreement.

     As Mdm Halimah has mentioned, Qantas Airways has recently announced its investment in a new low cost airline to be based in Singapore.   Singapore welcomes any foreign carrier to be

Column: 2700

involved in a LCC venture in Singapore, if the proposal strengthens our hub status.  In the case of Qantas, we welcome their decision as it will entrench their existing hub operations in Changi.  The low fares of the LCC will stimulate greater traffic volumes between Singapore and regional cities.   It would also enable Qantas to bring in more long-haul travellers from Europe and Australia to transit and transfer through Changi to the region.  It is likely that some of these new travellers will stop over in Singapore, hence creating more jobs and boosting our tourism receipts.  It is therefore in our national interest to have Qantas base its new LCC in Singapore and continue growing its hub operations here.

     The establishment of new LCCs in Singapore and other new airlines in the region will change the regional aviation landscape in the years ahead.  However, SIA will continue to share a symbiotic relationship with Changi and must continue to play an important role in enhancing our hub airport status.  Therefore, we will continue to further liberalise our air services agreements and increase our air rights with other countries.  With more air rights available, both SIA and other new Singapore carriers will be able to grow. In turn, their growth will strengthen Changi's role as a hub airport.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister how long does he think this process of negotiation leading to the conclusion of an open-skies agreement will take, considering that there is already stability and the fact that Qantas will be already flying from Singapore in view of the recent developments here?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:  Sir, I can assure the Member that we are engaging the Australian authorities and I intend to press the issue very strongly.

IMMIGRANTS

(Grant of Singapore citizenship)

4.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Prime Minister in view of the need to increase immigration as a solution to our declining fertility rate,  (a) what is the right number of immigrants as well as the timing under which they will be granted citizenship; (b) what are their required educational qualifications, skills and working experiences; and (c) how to assure Singaporeans that the increased immigration will not contradict our policy of nurturing committed and loyal Singaporeans and placing them at the core of our society.

     The Minister, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lim Hng Kiang) (for the Prime Minister):  Mr Speaker, Sir,   Singapore has been an immigrant society from the beginning.  Economic migrants from China and India, as well as Malays from the immediate neighbourhood, joined together and made Singapore what it is today.  Thus, welcoming with open arms those with something to contribute to our economy and society is not a new idea.  For those who can integrate well into our society, we want to encourage them to become permanent residents, and thereafter to take up citizenship.  They will make long-term contributions to the well-being of Singapore, and build up commitment and loyalty with time.  Their children, especially, will grow up in the local environment, studying in Singapore schools and serving National Service.   

           There is no correct number of immigrants to draw to Singapore.  The test is whether they will be adding to the Singapore economy and society, and how well we are able to absorb them.  But even while we welcome new immigrants, it is right that we differentiate appropriately between the privileges for the citizens as opposed to permanent residents, and of permanent residents as opposed to

Column: 2702

foreigners who are only temporarily in Singapore. 

           There is the citizen core which the Government will always specially recognise - they are the ones who are raised here, for whom Singapore is the only home, and for whom Singapore is not only worth living for, but also dying for.  Only they can vote, only they can buy HDB flats directly from the HDB at highly subsidised rates, only they can qualify for grants to purchase resale flats, only they qualify for asset enhancement programmes and such schemes as ERS and NSS. 

          What else can we do to acknowledge the role of our citizen core?


How do we attract more immigrants to sink roots in Singapore? The Working Committee on Population, as well as my Steering Group, are currently examining these issues and we will be presenting our proposals to the Government before August.

Column: 2702

NON-PROFIT ORGANISATIONS

(Guidelines on raising funds)

5.  Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) whether there are clear guidelines for non-profit organisations on raising funds from the public and on the utilisation of these funds; and (b) if there are, what is the monitoring mechanism in place to ensure compliance with these guidelines and thereby to ensure public confidence in such organisations.

     The Second Minister for Finance (Mr Lim Hng Kiang) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker Sir, it is important to have clear guidelines on the raising and utilisation of funds to maintain public confidence in our non-profit organisations and their programmes.   There are essentially three questions the public is most interested in.   First, what methods are used to raise the

Column: 2703

money?  Second, how much of the charity dollar is used to raise funds?  And, finally, how is the money spent or saved?

 

     The Government launched the Council on Governance for IPCs in January this year to look at best practices for IPCs.   IPC stands for Institution of a Public Character.  IPC status is conferred under the Income Tax Act.  IPCs are authorised to accept tax deductible donations from the public.  They are regulated by IRAS or by central fund administrators, which are organisations authorised by IRAS to grant IPC status to other organisations whose objectives are similar to theirs.

 

     The Council is chaired by Ms Lim Soo Hoon, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Community Development and Sports.  It has seven members from the people sector with wide experience in the local charity scene, and three members from the public sector.  The Council is studying ways to better improve fund-raising practices and ensure that IPCs' use of funds is transparent and in line with international best practices.  It is working on a code of best practices for the IPCs, and will also recommend how existing fund-raising regulations could be refined to better support informed giving.

 

     Let me now describe what the current rules are, which the Council will improve upon, as appropriate.

 

    First, on fund raising methods.  Today, we do not regulate fund-raising methods, except when fund-raising is conducted in public places.  This is then regulated by the Police under the House to House and Street Collections Act.   Under the House to House and Street Collections Act, any individual or organisation wishing to solicit donations in the streets or other public places is required to obtain a licence from the Police.  One of the conditions is that fund-raising expenses must not exceed 30% of the total funds raised.  Enforcement comes under the Police.

 

Column: 2704

     Second, on fund-raising efficiency.   IRAS also imposes a 30% limit on all fund-raising expenses by IPCs. The 30% limit is stipulated under Income Tax Regulations 2004 and enforcement is by IRAS and the central fund administrators.

 

     Third, on effecitive use of funds.   Currently, there are no benchmarks for measuring the effectiveness of IPCs as they cover a wide range of activities and charitable sectors.    The Council on Governance for IPCs will be studying this matter.  All IPCs are required to submit their audited financial accounts to IRAS and their central fund administrators every year.   IPCs are also required to post their financial reports online, hyperlinked to IRAS' website, so that the public can better scrutinise their use of funds.  This requirement to post financial information online began in 2002.  At that time, only about 15% of the IPCs or 170 of the bigger IPCs were required to post their key information online.   However, from 1st January 2004, all IPCs are required to post their financial information online to allow free public access.  Today, all 821 organisations with IPC status have done so.

 

     Donors have an important role to play in demanding accountability for the way their donations are used.   They should be aware of the financial needs of different IPCs, choose the charities they wish to support, and be satisfied about how their donations flow through to the beneficiaries.  IPCs, on the other hand, must understand that increasing accountability to the public is critical for ensuring a continuing flow of donations for their causes.  The Government believes that charity dollars will go up with informed giving.

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman (Sembawang): Sir, can I ask the Minister what is the basis for the 30% cap on the funds that can be used for fund-raising

Column: 2705

expenses?   Does the Minister think that this is high, eg, if we take a donation of $6 million which allows the organisation to use up to $1.8 million just for fund-raising expenses alone?  What is the basis and whether this is high in his opinion?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, our general approach to regulating the charities is to adopt a very light approach.  I think we do not want to over burden the charity sector with very tight regulations.  As Members know, the charity sector comprises a wide range of causes.  Some are very small organisations, others are larger organisations.  So, when we had this rule of 30% for fund-raising expenses, we were looking more at the majority of charities, which are much smaller organisations, and therefore to stipulate a 30% rule is not unreasonable, because the amounts they raise are small and the costs of overheads of raising funds are also high.  But, of course, if the organisation is large, then I will agree with the Member that 30% seems on the high side.  We urge all organisations to always look carefully at the amount they spend in raising each donation dollar and to make sure that this expense is kept as low as possible.


     Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, do I take it that it is also not within the remit of the Council on Governance to determine how much a charity or an IPC can keep as its reserve in its accounts in order to meet its future expenditures?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, as I mentioned, there is a wide range of charitable causes. Some require long-term commitments when they take on the role of looking after their beneficiaries and, therefore, it is prudent for them to have a sensible policy, especially those which are able to raise sufficient funds that will see them through multi-year projects.  So, we do not have a specific rule on how much chari

Column: 2706

ties should set aside for their reserves.  But we urge all charities to disclose this adequately in their statments.

     Mr Charles Chong (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Sir, could the Minister tell us whether the National Kidney Foundation is in full compliance with all the current guidelines that he mentioned just now in the collection and utilisation of the funds that it receives from the public?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the NKF is in full compliance with the regulations.

     The functions of the Public Service Commission (PSC) were devolved to a system of Personnel Boards by constitutional amendments in 1994.  To facilitate decision-making, Personnel Boards often assign individual members the authority to decide on the appointment, confirmation and emplacement, promotion and transfer of the public officers under the Boards' purview.  However, as the assigned member is only acting on behalf of the Board, the Board's covering approval is required.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:

     Ms Braema Mathi asked why we changed the operating hours.  The change was part of Police's ongoing efforts to optimise the deployment of its officers to deal more effectively with crime and potential terrorist threats.  Our records over the last five years show that demand for services at the NPPs has dropped by half.  Many people now go to one of the 31 Neighbourhood Police Centres instead, as these provide a broader range of services and are open round-the-clock.  Our records also show that 75% of the transactions at the NPPs take place between noon and 10 pm.  It therefore makes sense to change the operating hours to cater to this demand pattern.

 

     With this change in NPP operating hours, we can now put 65 more officers on active neighbourhood patrols, instead of having them at the NPPs.  A more mobile police will more effectively project police presence on the ground, for example, at markets and other high-traffic areas to deter crime.  At night, these officers can be deployed to patrol crime-prone areas and conduct anti-crime patrols and ambushes.

 

     Ms Mathi asked about the nature of the transactions at the NPPs.  The vast majority of transactions at NPPs are not urgent or critical.  These include changes of addresses, lost and found reports, and traffic reports. 

 

     For urgent matters, the public should contact the Police using the 999 hotline.  In addition, when the NPPs are closed, the public can use the Emergency Communications System found outside the NPPs or go to any of the 31 Neighbourhood Police Centres.

 

     Ms Mathi asked about the savings resulting from this change in the operating hours.  This change is to enhance operational effectiveness, not secure manpower savings.

 

     Lastly, Ms Mathi asked about the number of officers stationed at the Neighbourhood Police Posts during the new opening hours. REGISTERED CLUBS WITH JACKPOT AND GAMING ROOMS

     1.  Mdm Cynthia Phua asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) how many registered clubs in Singapore have jackpots and gaming rooms in 2003 compared with 2002 and (b) what are the criteria used to grant them the licences.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:

     In 2002, there were 107 registered clubs licensed to operate a total of 1,881 fruit machines (jackpot machines).  In 2003, the number of clubs remained unchanged, with a total of 1,891 fruit machines.  Registered clubs do not require a licence to operate gaming rooms with arcade-type amusement machines and, as such, we do not have the statistics.

 

     Permits are issued under the Private Lotteries Act for the use of fruit machines.  Applications for a permit to operate fruit machines will be considered only from registered members' clubs, which are not primarily set up for gaming, wagering or conducting lotteries.  In addition, the club must have operated for at least one year and have at least 500 voting members for the past one year.  Clubs are also required to pay a deposit of $10,000 per fruit machine.  No profits are allowed to accrue to any individual from the operation of the machines and in the event that the club is dissolved, money accruing from the fruit machines must be donated to a charitable organisation or a fund approved by the Commissioner of Estate Duties.

SERVICES AND FUNDING FOR THE DISABLED

     3.  Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Minister for Community Development and Sports what are the services (both residential and day-care) and funding available to (i) disabled adults aged 60 years and below, who were disabled in road accidents or through

strokes and (ii) adults aged between 50 and 60 years who are frail and do not qualify for nursing home care but who need assistance for daily living activities.

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:

     Community-based Services

 

     There is a range of community-based services available to people with disabilities who are either disabled from birth or as a result of a traffic accident or stroke.  One such facility is the Day Activity Centre for people with disabilities, which provides alternative care arrangements to relieve caregivers from looking after their disabled family members during the day.  At Day Activity Centres, clients learn or re-learn skills for daily living.  MCDS provides both capital funding for these centres as well as recurrent funding for the running of the programme.

 

     Day Activity Centres generally take in persons aged 16-55.  For persons beyond age 55, a review is made to assess the suitability of the client for continued care at the Day Activity Centre or for transfer to a Day Care Centre for the Elderly.  Clients at the elderly day care centres are means-tested and are given subsidies, if eligible, depending on their household income.

 

     For older adults who are frail and aged between 50 and 60 years, they can obtain support either from day care centres or home help services.  Although these services are targeted more at the older group (those above 55 years old), they can be extended to adults under 55 years on a case-by-case basis.  MCDS provides subsidies to users of day care centres (through the means test framework) and the home help service. 

 

     The Ministry of Health also oversees several Day Rehabilitation Centres across the island which provide outpatient rehabilitation to help Singaporeans who become disabled as a result of an accident or stroke. Subsidies are given based on the means testing framework as well, for needy clients.

 

Residential Institutions

 

     If a disabled person requires full-time care that cannot be catered for in the community, there are residential options.  A person who is assessed to have rehabilitation potential can be admitted to Community Hospitals for short term in-patient rehabilitation to improve functional abilities.  Long-term care facilities such as chronic sick hospitals or nursing homes cater to those who have maximised their rehabilitation potential and still require continuing and nursing care. 

 

     MCDS also works with Voluntary Welfare Organisations to set up and run Homes for disabled adults at all ages.  Besides providing long-term residential care for persons with disabilities who are either destitute, neglected or whose caregivers are unable or incapable of caring for them, these Homes also provide short-term respite care for families who require the service.  Residents are subsidised according to their household income.  MCDS is currently doing a review of the Homes for disabled adults.  One of the objectives of the review is to standardise referral and admission criteria and procedures to the Homes.  This will ensure that the service is made available to people who require it.
